q3.value: The jamais vu experience is a brief sensation of unfamiliarity about something known to be familiar (Moulin, 2017). Often considered as the opposite of the déjà vu experience, jamais vu could be conceptualised as an epistemic feeling at the same level as déjà vu or TOT (Moulin, Bell, Turunen, Baharin & O'Connor, 2020), and could provide an additional evidence of the monitoring function. Several studies suggest a decline in that metacognitive abilities in ageing (Pansky, Goldsmith & Koriat, 2009; Vance, 2006), and Mecacci & Righi (2006) have shown that older adults are less likely than younger adults to report cognitive failures. Moreover, it seems that older adults are less sensitive to the semantic satiation phenomenon (Balota & Black, 1997) and also less sensitive to the déjà vu experience (Moulin, Souchay, Buchanan, Bradley, Karadoller & Akan, 2014). Given all these evidences, we expect older adults to be less sensitive to the jamais vu experience.

q4.value:
We have two main hypotheses: 
- Firstly, we expect older adults to report fewer jamais vu sensations than younger adults.
- Secondly, the difference in reaction times between trials that generated jamais vu sensations and trials that did not should increase as a function of the staring time, and we expect this difference to be greater for young adults than for older adults.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
Mixed design with 3 factors : 
- Age (between subjects): young and older adults
- Staring time (within subjects): 3, 15 and 30 seconds 
- Type of trial (within subjects): trials that generated jamais vu and trials that did not

q9.value: Two lists of words have been created: odds participants will be assigned to list 1 while even participants will have list 2. In each list, all conditions will be counterbalanced from a subject to another, and trials will be randomly displayed.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Young participants will be recruited from psychological classes and will be rewarded with an experiment voucher. Older adults will be recruited by word of mouth and must be between 60 and 80 years old. They will have to be healthy, so they must not have any neuropsychological disorder. In order to test this, we will perform a MMSE and exclude all participants with deficiency scores. 
All participants should have a normal or corrected to normal view, be native French speakers and fill a consent form before the experiment begins.

q13.value: Our target sample size is 82 participants.

q14.value: We used the software program G*Power to conduct a power analysis. Our goal was to obtain .95 power to detect a large effect size of .74 at the standard .05 alpha error probability.

question.value:
We manipulated three variables: 
- The age group of participants (young and older adults)
- The staring time of stimuli (3, 15 and 30 seconds)
- The type of trials (those that generated jamais vu sensation and those that did not).
The single dependant variable will be the reaction time at the semantic decision task.
We will take participant's reaction times in order to create a mean reaction time for each participant as a function of independent variables.

In order to test the first hypothesis, we will use a t-test with the age group as independent factor, and the number of jamais vu sensations reported as dependant factor. 
In order to test the second hypothesis, we will use a mixed model analysis (equivalent to a mixed ANOVA) with the age group as between subjects factor, and the type of trials and the staring time as within subjects factors.

q20.value: If residuals will not follow a normal distribution, we will apply a logarithmic transformation in order to normalise the residuals.

q21.value: We will use the standard p<.05 criteria for determining if the ANOVA suggest that the results are significantly different from those expected if the null hypothesis were correct. In case of non effect, we will use a Bayes factor analysis to estimate the prevalence of the "non-effect".

q22.value: Outliers will be detected using the absolute deviation around the median, which is a more robust measure of dispersion than the standard deviation around the mean (Leys, Ley, Klein, Bernard & Licata, 2013).

q23.value: In our procedure, there can't be any missing data because a response is needed to pass to the next trial.

q24.value: We will look more closely the relationship between the frequency of déjà vu and jamais vu in daily life and run a correlation in order to test this.

attributes.title: Relative gratification and Negative Attitudes towards Immigrants

q1.value: Relative Gratification and Negative Attitudes against Immigrants – a Replication of the V-Curve and Investigation of Explaining Factors (Master Thesis)

q2.value: Hannah Arnu, Susanne Veit, Ulrich Klocke

q3.value: Immigration has become subject to intense discussions in most Western societies in recent years. Explaining negative attitudes and prejudice against immigrants has long been an aim of social psychological research. One important theoretical approach, the one of relative deprivation theory, has recently been complemented by the concept of relative gratification: some studies show that not only relative deprivation, but also the feeling of relative gratification can lead to more prejudice. This non-linear, v-shaped relationship between relative status and prejudice is supposed to be replicated in this study drawing on an experiment by Jetten, Mols and Postmes (2015) that manipulates the feeling of relative deprivation/gratification by randomly assigning participants to an income group in a fictitious society and measuring their attitudes towards immigrants afterwards. Furthermore, the potential moderating effects of both personality-related concepts such as social dominance orientation and belief in a just world, as well as the context-related factor perception of economic instability will be examined. A potential underlying mediation of the effect of relative status on negative attitudes through the fear for the status of the own group will be investigated. The results can give insight in the understudied effects of relative gratification on negative attitudes against immigrants.

q4.value:
H1: Both experimental groups (relative deprivation and relative gratification) will report significantly more negative attitudes towards immigrants compared to the control group (v-curve-hypothesis). 

H2a: In the instability condition, all groups will report significantly more negative attitudes towards immigrants compared to the stability condition (main effect instability). 

H2b: There is a significant interaction between the experimental factors relative gratification and stability (instability vs. stability). The positive effect of relative gratification on opposition to immigration will be reinforced in the instability condition. 

H3: The positive effect of relative gratification on opposition to immigration is partly mediated by the fear for the future status of the own group (status anxiety). 

H4: A high manifestation of social dominance orientation reinforces the positive effect of relative gratification on opposition to immigration (interaction RG x SDO)

H5: A high manifestation of a belief in a just world reinforces the positive effect of relative gratification on opposition to immigration (interaction RG x BJW)

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

q7.value: Partial blinding; participants will only know the income group they have been assigned to. They will not know that other participants are assigned to other treatment groups. They will not know that they have been assigned to a treatment group in the manipulation of stability.

question.value: The study has a between-subjects design with 2 factors: relative status (3 levels: relative deprivation, control group, relative gratification) and stability of the economy (2 levels: instability, stability). Further potential moderators (SDO, belief in a just world) are measured for all participants.

q9.value: We will use a simple randomization technique for each factor. Random assignment to the experimental condition will be generated with an implemented function of limesurvey (the online survey tool we use).

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
The data will be collected through an online experiment. As we are aiming for a sample as similar as possible to the original study (young undergraduate students), participants will be recruited through a range of suitable university mailing lists and students’ Facebook groups, which have been collected as useful accesses to participants by graduating students at Humboldt University over the years.  Participants must be at least 18 and able to give their consent to the participation in the study. They will not receive payment for their participation. Study timeline: Data collection will be started in the beginning of March 2020. Before the main data collection, one prestudy was conducted in order to validate the selection of pictures for the experiment (convenience sample N = 15). As a second prestudy, participants were shown the survey for the main data collection and asked for feedback.

Prior to data collection, a questionnaire for self-rating the adherence to ethical standards in a fast-track-procedure (provided by Technische Universität Berlin) was answered. The document is attached to this question. As no question was answered with "Yes", no further clearance from an ethical committee was needed.

q13.value: Our target sample size is 300 participants.

q14.value: In order to determine our sample size, we conducted a power analysis with the software program G*Power for the multiple regression analysis. Aiming for detecting a medium effect size of .15, with .95 power and at the standard alpha error probability of .05, an analysis with 9 predictors should have a total sample size of N = 166. Taking into consideration that we will also perform a mediation analysis and that there might be some missing data in the observations, we opted for a sample size of N = 300.

q15.value: We will stop our data collection if a maximum sample size of 500 participants will be reached or three weeks have passed and a minimum sample size of 250 participants is reached.

question.value:
Relative status: we will manipulate the relative status of participants by assigning them to one of three income groups in a fictitious society. The feeling of relative deprivation/ gratification is supposed to be elicited by giving participants the possibility to choose between houses, holidays and cars within their income bracket. Pictures of houses, cars and holidays were selected through a prestudy. The material of the original paradigm used by Jetten (2015) was translated into German and backtranslated by an English native speaker to ensure the consistency with the original.
Stability: The stability of the economy in the fictitious society will be manipulated by assigning participants to one of two conditions: instability vs. stability. The impression of (in-)stability is supposed to be elicited by reading a fictitious newspaper article, either claiming that there soon might be a severe economic crisis or that the economy is stable in the fictitious society.

All items that had to be translated from English to German were also backtranslated into English by an English native speaker in order to ensure the consistency with the original.

Outcome (Dependent variable): opposition to immigration
We will use an adapted and shorter version of the items used in the original study by Jetten et al. (2015). The subscales are symbolic threat, realistic threat, and general items. Please find the items (in German) below. Items will be measured on a scale from 1 (“do not agree at all”) to 7 (“fully agree”). In the original study by Jetten et al. (2015), alpha was .91 for the opposition to immigration scale. 

Symbolic threat: 
-	Die Kultur der neuen Gruppe wird die barolische Lebensweise bedrohen. 
-	Die barolische Identität wird durch die Anwesenheit der Neuankömmlinge bedroht.
-	Immigration nach Barolien untergräbt die barolische Kultur. 

Realistic threat: 
-	Leute aus der neuen Gruppe werden Sozialleistungen missbrauchen.
-	Die Arbeitslosigkeit in Barolien wird durch die Anwesenheit der neuen Gruppe steigen. 
-	An Schulen, in denen zu viele Kinder aus der neuen Gruppe sind, wird die Qualität der Bildung leiden. 

General items / restrictive policies: 
-	Ich denke, unsere Gruppe sollte keine Neuankömmlinge in Barolien erlauben.
-	Ich fühle mich verantwortlich, der neuen Gruppe zu helfen. (-)
-	Dass diese neue Gruppe nach Barolien kommt, bereitet mir Sorgen. 


Mediator: Status anxiety
The potential mediator of the effect of relative gratification on opposition to immigration, status anxiety, will be measured with 6 items translated and adapted for the experimental context from the original study by Jetten et al. (2015) and from a scale called collective angst that the author provided and that she used in other studies (such as Jetten, J., Mols, F., Healy, N., & Spears, R. 2017). For the collective angst scale, alpha was .95 in the original study by Jetten et al. (2017).

-	Ich bin zuversichtlich, dass sich die Situation meiner eigenen Gruppe nicht ändern wird, wenn eine neue Gruppe kommt. 
-	Ich bin zuversichtlich, dass meine Gruppe jegliche äußerliche Bedrohung überstehen wird. 
-	Ich mache mir Sorgen um das zukünftige Wohlergehen meiner Einkommensgruppe in Barolien. 
-	Ich bin ängstlich in Bezug auf den zukünftigen Wohlstand meiner Einkommensgruppe. 
-	Ich habe den Eindruck, dass sich die Dinge für meine Einkommensgruppe zum Schlechten wenden. 
-	Was die Zukunft meiner Einkommensgruppe angeht, bin ich positiv gestimmt. 



Moderators: 
Social Dominance Orientation
The potential moderator Social Dominance Orientation will be measured with the normed and validated German short version of the scale by Aichholzer (2019) (alpha = .74). Please find the items below. 
-	Jede Gesellschaft braucht Gruppen, die oben sind und andere, die unten sind.
-	Der Versuch, alle sozialen Gruppen gleich zu machen, ist ungerecht.
-	Gleiche Chancen für alle sozialen Gruppen müssen oberstes Ziel sein. (-) 

Belief in a just world 
The general belief in a just world will be measured with a translated and normed version of the Belief in a Just World scale, the “Allgemeiner Gerechte-Welt-Glaube” scale by Schmitt et al. (2007). Please find the items below. The internal consistency of the scale was α = .83.
-	Ich finde, dass es auf der Welt im Allgemeinen gerecht zugeht.
-	Ich glaube, dass die Leute im Großen und Ganzen das bekommen, was ihnen gerechterweise zusteht.
-	Ich bin sicher, dass immer wieder die Gerechtigkeit in der Welt die Oberhand gewinnt.
-	Ich bin überzeugt, dass irgendwann jede/r für erlittene Ungerechtigkeit entschädigt wird.
-	Ungerechtigkeiten sind nach meiner Auffassung in allen Lebensbereichen (z.B. Beruf, Familie, Politik) eher die Ausnahme als die Regel.
-	Ich denke, dass sich bei wichtigen Entscheidungen alle Beteiligten um Gerechtigkeit bemühen.


Manipulation checks: Successful manipulation of the feeling of relative deprivation / gratification and the perception of (in-)stability will be measured with items that are closely linked to the manipulation checks in the original study. For checking whether the manipulation of status was successful, the participants are asked: 

-	Meine Gruppe ist relativ... 
o	1) arm … 7) reich

The effect of the manipulation of stability is measured by asking participants: 
-	Bitte geben Sie nun an, für wie passend Sie die folgenden Begriffe für die Situation in Barolien halten. (Scale: 1) sehr unpassend – 7) sehr passend)
o	Stabilität 
o	Unsicherheit


Demographics: A range of demographic items, such as age, gender, main occupation, field of study (for students), socioeconomic background, device used for answering the survey etc. will be asked in a final part of the study.

The dependent variable will be combined into an index for “opposition to immigration”. After confirming the supposed factorial structure (symbolic threat, realistic threat, general items) with a factor analysis, it will be calculated using a mean. 
After respective factorial investigation, a mean will also be calculated for all items of the potential mediator “status anxiety”. The same holds true for the moderators SDO and Belief in a Just World. Reversed items will be recoded prior to creating an index.

For all statistical analyses, RStudio (Version 1.2.5019) will be used. 

Manipulation checks: 
First, the successful manipulation of the experimental factors will be tested. To that end, one-way between-subjects ANOVAs will be used for each experimental factor (relative status and economic instability). The scores on the manipulation check items are expected to show the following pattern in a post-hoc analysis: 
-	Perceived status: RD < CG < RG
-	Perceived stability: instability < stability 

For the main analysis, a multiple regression approach will be used. “Opposition to immigration” will be the outcome, while the predictors include: 
-	Relative status: 2 dummy-coded variables RD vs. CG and RG vs. CG
-	Relative stability: 1 dichotomous variable stability vs. instability 
-	SDO
-	Belief in a Just World 

Furthermore, interaction terms will be included in the analysis: 
-	Relative Gratification (RG vs. CG) x Stability (stability vs. instability) 
-	Relative Gratification (RG vs. CG) x SDO
-	Relative Gratification (RG vs. CG) x Belief in a Just World 

For the mediation analysis, a path analysis approach will be used. More specifically, we will use a simplified SEM approach and include the supposed mediating variable in a stepwise manner in different regression models. The direct and indirect effects will be calculated accordingly. The analysis will include bias-corrected bootstrapping to test the coefficients and confidence intervals. Eventually, the goodness-of-fit of the mediation model will be evaluated (see inference criteria). 


In order to control for the potential influence of other covariates, the following variables are relevant: 
-	Age
-	Gender 
-	Time needed for completing the survey 
-	Device used for completing the survey

q20.value:
As described above, the experimental factor relative status will be dummy coded: 
RG vs. CG and RD vs. CG with “CG” as the reference category. 
We will also use standardized regression coefficients in order to make comparisons between the predictors easier.

q21.value: For determining the significance of results in all relevant analyses (ANOVA for manipulation checks, as well as significance of predictors and determination coefficients in regression models) we will use the standard p<.05 criteria. For the mediation analysis, we will use bootstrapping in order to investigate the coefficients and confidence intervals. The goodness-of-fit of the mediation model will be evaluated drawing on the criteria by Hu & Bentler (1999).

q22.value: We might exclude participants with conspicuous response patterns such as extremely long answering times and indications of response biases.

q23.value: When the survey is not completed until the last page, this has to be interpreted as a withdrawal of consent according to our ethical standards and therefore, the data will be excluded.

q24.value: We expect that certain demographic traits may be related to the effect of relative gratification on opposition to immigration. Therefore, we will look for relationships between demographic variables (age, gender, actual socioeconomic background and education) and the primary outcome. We are also interested in finding out if the expected effect of relative status on opposition to immigration is differentiated for the three subscales of the dependent variable (symbolic threat, realistic threat, general items). Furthermore, the effect of relative deprivation on opposition to immigration and its relationship to mediators and moderators is not the focus of this study but will still be explored.

q25.value:
Literature cited:

Aichholzer, J. (2019). Kurzskala Soziale Dominanzorientierung (KSDO-3). Zusammenstellung sozialwissenschaftlicher Items und Skalen (ZIS). https://doi.org/10.6102/zis269

Hu, L. T., & Bentler, P. M. (1999). Cutoff criteria for fit indexes in covariance structure analysis: Conventional criteria versus new alternatives. Structural equation modeling: a multidisciplinary journal, 6(1), 1-55.

Jetten, J., Mols, F., & Postmes, T. (2015). Relative Deprivation and Relative Wealth Enhances Anti-Immigrant Sentiments : The V- Curve Re-Examined. PLoS ONE, 10(10), 1–24. https://doi.org/10.1371/journal.pone.0139156

Schmitt, M., Dalbert, C., Montada, L., Gschwendner, T., Maes, J., Reichle, B., … Brähler, E. (2008). Verteilung des Glaubens an eine gerechte Welt in der Allgemeinbevölkerung: Normwerte für die Skala Allgemeiner Gerechte-Welt-Glaube. Diagnostica, 54(3), 150–163. https://doi.org/10.1026/0012-1924.54.3.150

Jetten, J., Mols, F., Healy, N., & Spears, R. (2017). “Fear of Falling”: Economic Instability Enhances Collective Angst among Societies’ Wealthy Class. Journal of Social Issues, 73(1), 61–79. https://doi.org/10.1111/josi.12204

registration_responses.q22: We might exclude participants with conspicuous response patterns such as extremely long answering times and indications of response biases.
registration_responses.q23: When the survey is not completed until the last page, this has to be interpreted as a withdrawal of consent according to our ethical standards and therefore, the data will be excluded.
registration_responses.q24: We expect that certain demographic traits may be related to the effect of relative gratification on opposition to immigration. Therefore, we will look for relationships between demographic variables (age, gender, actual socioeconomic background and education) and the primary outcome. We are also interested in finding out if the expected effect of relative status on opposition to immigration is differentiated for the three subscales of the dependent variable (symbolic threat, realistic threat, general items). Furthermore, the effect of relative deprivation on opposition to immigration and its relationship to mediators and moderators is not the focus of this study but will still be explored.

registration_responses.q8.question: The study has a between-subjects design with 2 factors: relative status (3 levels: relative deprivation, control group, relative gratification) and stability of the economy (2 levels: instability, stability). Further potential moderators (SDO, belief in a just world) are measured for all participants.
registration_responses.q12.question:
The data will be collected through an online experiment. As we are aiming for a sample as similar as possible to the original study (young undergraduate students), participants will be recruited through a range of suitable university mailing lists and students’ Facebook groups, which have been collected as useful accesses to participants by graduating students at Humboldt University over the years.  Participants must be at least 18 and able to give their consent to the participation in the study. They will not receive payment for their participation. Study timeline: Data collection will be started in the beginning of March 2020. Before the main data collection, one prestudy was conducted in order to validate the selection of pictures for the experiment (convenience sample N = 15). As a second prestudy, participants were shown the survey for the main data collection and asked for feedback.

Prior to data collection, a questionnaire for self-rating the adherence to ethical standards in a fast-track-procedure (provided by Technische Universität Berlin) was answered. The document is attached to this question. As no question was answered with "Yes", no further clearance from an ethical committee was needed.
registration_responses.q16.question:
Relative status: we will manipulate the relative status of participants by assigning them to one of three income groups in a fictitious society. The feeling of relative deprivation/ gratification is supposed to be elicited by giving participants the possibility to choose between houses, holidays and cars within their income bracket. Pictures of houses, cars and holidays were selected through a prestudy. The material of the original paradigm used by Jetten (2015) was translated into German and backtranslated by an English native speaker to ensure the consistency with the original.
Stability: The stability of the economy in the fictitious society will be manipulated by assigning participants to one of two conditions: instability vs. stability. The impression of (in-)stability is supposed to be elicited by reading a fictitious newspaper article, either claiming that there soon might be a severe economic crisis or that the economy is stable in the fictitious society.
registration_responses.q17.question:
All items that had to be translated from English to German were also backtranslated into English by an English native speaker in order to ensure the consistency with the original.

Outcome (Dependent variable): opposition to immigration
We will use an adapted and shorter version of the items used in the original study by Jetten et al. (2015). The subscales are symbolic threat, realistic threat, and general items. Please find the items (in German) below. Items will be measured on a scale from 1 (“do not agree at all”) to 7 (“fully agree”). In the original study by Jetten et al. (2015), alpha was .91 for the opposition to immigration scale. 

Symbolic threat: 
-	Die Kultur der neuen Gruppe wird die barolische Lebensweise bedrohen. 
-	Die barolische Identität wird durch die Anwesenheit der Neuankömmlinge bedroht.
-	Immigration nach Barolien untergräbt die barolische Kultur. 

Realistic threat: 
-	Leute aus der neuen Gruppe werden Sozialleistungen missbrauchen.
-	Die Arbeitslosigkeit in Barolien wird durch die Anwesenheit der neuen Gruppe steigen. 
-	An Schulen, in denen zu viele Kinder aus der neuen Gruppe sind, wird die Qualität der Bildung leiden. 

General items / restrictive policies: 
-	Ich denke, unsere Gruppe sollte keine Neuankömmlinge in Barolien erlauben.
-	Ich fühle mich verantwortlich, der neuen Gruppe zu helfen. (-)
-	Dass diese neue Gruppe nach Barolien kommt, bereitet mir Sorgen. 


Mediator: Status anxiety
The potential mediator of the effect of relative gratification on opposition to immigration, status anxiety, will be measured with 6 items translated and adapted for the experimental context from the original study by Jetten et al. (2015) and from a scale called collective angst that the author provided and that she used in other studies (such as Jetten, J., Mols, F., Healy, N., & Spears, R. 2017). For the collective angst scale, alpha was .95 in the original study by Jetten et al. (2017).

-	Ich bin zuversichtlich, dass sich die Situation meiner eigenen Gruppe nicht ändern wird, wenn eine neue Gruppe kommt. 
-	Ich bin zuversichtlich, dass meine Gruppe jegliche äußerliche Bedrohung überstehen wird. 
-	Ich mache mir Sorgen um das zukünftige Wohlergehen meiner Einkommensgruppe in Barolien. 
-	Ich bin ängstlich in Bezug auf den zukünftigen Wohlstand meiner Einkommensgruppe. 
-	Ich habe den Eindruck, dass sich die Dinge für meine Einkommensgruppe zum Schlechten wenden. 
-	Was die Zukunft meiner Einkommensgruppe angeht, bin ich positiv gestimmt. 



Moderators: 
Social Dominance Orientation
The potential moderator Social Dominance Orientation will be measured with the normed and validated German short version of the scale by Aichholzer (2019) (alpha = .74). Please find the items below. 
-	Jede Gesellschaft braucht Gruppen, die oben sind und andere, die unten sind.
-	Der Versuch, alle sozialen Gruppen gleich zu machen, ist ungerecht.
-	Gleiche Chancen für alle sozialen Gruppen müssen oberstes Ziel sein. (-) 

Belief in a just world 
The general belief in a just world will be measured with a translated and normed version of the Belief in a Just World scale, the “Allgemeiner Gerechte-Welt-Glaube” scale by Schmitt et al. (2007). Please find the items below. The internal consistency of the scale was α = .83.
-	Ich finde, dass es auf der Welt im Allgemeinen gerecht zugeht.
-	Ich glaube, dass die Leute im Großen und Ganzen das bekommen, was ihnen gerechterweise zusteht.
-	Ich bin sicher, dass immer wieder die Gerechtigkeit in der Welt die Oberhand gewinnt.
-	Ich bin überzeugt, dass irgendwann jede/r für erlittene Ungerechtigkeit entschädigt wird.
-	Ungerechtigkeiten sind nach meiner Auffassung in allen Lebensbereichen (z.B. Beruf, Familie, Politik) eher die Ausnahme als die Regel.
-	Ich denke, dass sich bei wichtigen Entscheidungen alle Beteiligten um Gerechtigkeit bemühen.


Manipulation checks: Successful manipulation of the feeling of relative deprivation / gratification and the perception of (in-)stability will be measured with items that are closely linked to the manipulation checks in the original study. For checking whether the manipulation of status was successful, the participants are asked: 

-	Meine Gruppe ist relativ... 
o	1) arm … 7) reich

The effect of the manipulation of stability is measured by asking participants: 
-	Bitte geben Sie nun an, für wie passend Sie die folgenden Begriffe für die Situation in Barolien halten. (Scale: 1) sehr unpassend – 7) sehr passend)
o	Stabilität 
o	Unsicherheit


Demographics: A range of demographic items, such as age, gender, main occupation, field of study (for students), socioeconomic background, device used for answering the survey etc. will be asked in a final part of the study.
registration_responses.q18.question:
The dependent variable will be combined into an index for “opposition to immigration”. After confirming the supposed factorial structure (symbolic threat, realistic threat, general items) with a factor analysis, it will be calculated using a mean. 
After respective factorial investigation, a mean will also be calculated for all items of the potential mediator “status anxiety”. The same holds true for the moderators SDO and Belief in a Just World. Reversed items will be recoded prior to creating an index.
registration_responses.q19.question:
For all statistical analyses, RStudio (Version 1.2.5019) will be used. 

Manipulation checks: 
First, the successful manipulation of the experimental factors will be tested. To that end, one-way between-subjects ANOVAs will be used for each experimental factor (relative status and economic instability). The scores on the manipulation check items are expected to show the following pattern in a post-hoc analysis: 
-	Perceived status: RD < CG < RG
-	Perceived stability: instability < stability 

For the main analysis, a multiple regression approach will be used. “Opposition to immigration” will be the outcome, while the predictors include: 
-	Relative status: 2 dummy-coded variables RD vs. CG and RG vs. CG
-	Relative stability: 1 dichotomous variable stability vs. instability 
-	SDO
-	Belief in a Just World 

Furthermore, interaction terms will be included in the analysis: 
-	Relative Gratification (RG vs. CG) x Stability (stability vs. instability) 
-	Relative Gratification (RG vs. CG) x SDO
-	Relative Gratification (RG vs. CG) x Belief in a Just World 

For the mediation analysis, a path analysis approach will be used. More specifically, we will use a simplified SEM approach and include the supposed mediating variable in a stepwise manner in different regression models. The direct and indirect effects will be calculated accordingly. The analysis will include bias-corrected bootstrapping to test the coefficients and confidence intervals. Eventually, the goodness-of-fit of the mediation model will be evaluated (see inference criteria). 


In order to control for the potential influence of other covariates, the following variables are relevant: 
-	Age
-	Gender 
-	Time needed for completing the survey 
-	Device used for completing the survey

q1.value: It's a Wrap! Visualisations that Wrap Around Spherical, Cylindrical or Torus Topologies

q2.value: Kun-Ting Chen, Tim Dwyer, Benjamin Bach, Kim Marriott

q3.value: Identifying clusters or hubs in a large network graph is difficult especially when graph density is high and there are many crossing links. In this study, we investigate drawing a network graph by wrapping the links at the top and bottom, at the left and right of a window. This sometimes gives us the benefits of untangling a dense core. Furthermore, it allows us to avoid crossing links. We study how we can best visualise large graphs on the torus. Furthermore, we study whether larger graphs such as community networks, scale-free graphs can be understandable though untangling the dense network. Specifically, we study whether people can identify clusters or hubs using torus graph with interactive panning. Furthermore, we investigate what perceptual benefits torus graph has over standard node-link representation.

q4.value:
Predictions
1.    Cluster identification task:

Effect of layout
-       L1: Pannable Torus graph has better (participant reported) task effectiveness than Node-link independent of difficulty levels.
-       L2: Node-link has better (participant reported) task effectiveness than Pannable Torus display (requires certain panning and mental wrapping) for easy tasks
-       L3: Pannable Torus graph has better (participant reported) task effectiveness than Node-link for difficult tasks

Participant Preference
-       P1: Participants will prefer Pannable Torus over Node-link.
-       P2: Participants will report more confidence in using Pannable Torus than Node-link.
 
2.    Belong to Cluster task

Effect of layout
-       L1: Pannable Torus graph has better (participant reported) task effectiveness than Node-link independent of difficulty levels.
-       L3: Pannable Torus graph has better (participant reported) task effectiveness than Node-link for both easy and difficult tasks

Participant Preference
-       P1: Participants will prefer Pannable Torus over Node-link.
-       P2: Participants will report more confidence in using Pannable Torus than Node-link.


3.    Hubs Identification task
Effect of layout
-       L1: Pannable Torus graph has better (participant reported) task effectiveness than Node-link independent of difficulty levels.
-       L3: Pannable Torus graph has better (participant reported) task effectiveness than Node-link for both easy and difficult tasks

Participant Preference
-       P1: Participants will prefer Pannable Torus over Node-link.

q1.value: Attitudinal cross-protection against health misinformation through inoculation.

q2.value: Melisa Basol, Dr. Sander van der Linden

q3.value: Although conferring attitudinal resistance through inoculation has been demonstrated in an array of contexts, very little research has examined the possibility of cross-protection conferred through inoculation. Indeed, Parker and colleagues (2016) were among the first to demonstrate that an inoculation message targeting one topic can confer resistance to conceptually related topics. As equally indicated by the authors, some more specific insights into the mechanisms and boundaries of cross-protection are required. Thus, this suggested study aims to examine whether cross-protection to health misinformation can be conferred through inoculation.

q4.value:
Hypothesis 1: Compared to the control condition, inoculated participants who receive either of the attack messages addressing the safety and efficacy of the target attitude (vaccines) will demonstrate a general attitudinal resistance (blanket of protection) to either attack message (same or different arguments to inoculation message).  

Hypothesis 2:  Compared to the individuals who were exposed to the attack message that addressed the same arguments as the inoculation treatment on vaccine safety and efficacy,  participants who are exposed to an attack message using different arguments will report (a) equal if not less attitude change, (b) perceived threat, (c) and counterarguing. 

Hypothesis 3: Compared to the control group, participants who receive an inoculation message addressing the safety and efficacy of vaccines (a) will perceive greater levels of threat, (b) are more likely to counterargue, and (c) will experience less negative attitude change in response to either attack message (same/different arguments) against vaccines. 

Hypothesis 4: Compared to the control condition, participants who receive an inoculation message addressing the efficacy and safety of vaccines will (a) report greater counterarguing and (b) perceived threat to their attitudes about (1) GMO, (2) blood donations, and (3) abortion. This is not expected to be present for (4) autonomous vehicles. 

Hypothesis 5: Compared to participants in the control condition, participants who receive an inoculation message addressing the safety and efficacy of vaccines report less (negative) attitude change in response to messages attacking the safety of (1) GMO, (2) blood donations, and (3) abortion. This is not expected to be present for (4) autonomous vehicles.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value:
This study will implement a 2-phase procedure, applying a 2 (treatment vs. control condition) x 5 (attitude topic) between-subject design. Whilst the independent variable will consist of treatment conditions (inoculation, control),  the dependent variables will constitute of pre- and post-test measures (attitudes, perceived threat, counterarguing, public support) - measured through semantic differential items similar to previous research (Ivanov et a., 2016). This proposed study received ethical approval from the Psychology Research Ethics Committee.  

Procedure: In Phase 1, all participants will complete a pre-test which will require them to fill out attitude scales towards the target topic (vaccines) and the related topics (e.g. GMO, abortion). Then, participants will be randomly assigned to either the control condition or the inoculation condition. Whilst the control condition will be exposed to a neutral and unrelated article, participants in the inoculation condition will be exposed to a paragraph (1) warning about common arguments against vaccine safety and efficacy (2) and providing counterarguments against these arguments. All participants will then be asked to complete the Post-treatment measures (Threat, perceived resistance, confidence, perceived medical consensus + risk, public support). 

After a 1 week delay, all participants will be recontacted to take part in Phase 2 of the study. Here, all participants will be presented with one of two attack messages addressing the target topic (vaccines). Specifically, participants will either read an attack message addressing the same arguments as the inoculation message in Phase 1 (attack_same) or an attack message that uses different arguments (attack_diff). After exposure to either attack_target message, all participants will be exposed to 4 attack messages on the related topics (GMO, abortion, blood donations, AV). Whilst these will be randomised, participants will be required to complete a few measures after each message (counterarguing, perceived resistance, and confidence). After having been exposed to all attack messages, participants will complete the Post-test t2. 

A study-flow chart has been attached for additional clarity.

q9.value: This study will utilise block randomisation, where each participant will be randomly assigned to one of the three equally sized, predetermined treatment conditions.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

q11.value: The only pre-existing data used in this study is a pilot test that required participants (N=130) to fill out attitude scales on a number of topics (e.g. climate change, immigration, autonomous vehicles, blood donations etc.). Correlational analyses allowed to determine which attitudes were correlated with attitudes towards the target topic (vaccination) of the proposed study. Thus, results informed the proposed research to include attitudes towards GMO, abortion, blood donation, and an uncorrelated topic, attitudes towards AV when testing whether inoculation can confer cross-protection across health misinformation.

question.value: Participants (n= 350)  will be recruited through an online crowd-sourcing platform Prolific Academic. The advertisement will suggest that the study aims to examine opinion on current media topics and will offer a compensation rate of £1.04 for their participation in Part 1 (estimated completion time approx. 10 min) and £0.74 for the follow-up study a week later (approx. completion time: 5 min). Inclusion criteria require participants to be at least 18 years old and speak English fluently.

q13.value: Based on the power analysis conducted prior to data collection, the required sample size is 296. As we expect some attrition in the follow-up, we will attempt to recruit up to 350 participants.

q14.value: Taking the average effect size from previous cross-protection research (Ivanov et al., 2016), a G*power analysis was conducted with α = 0.05, F= 3.02 (d= 0.21) and power of 0.95 with four experimental conditions (Phase 2 split into attack_same/attack_diff for both inoculation and control condition). The minimal sample size required for measuring the main effect was approximately 296.

question.value: In this study, the attack message will be manipulated. Thus, in the second phase of the study, participants will either be exposed to (1) an attack message addressing the same arguments as the inoculation message (attack_same) or (2) an attack message raising different arguments against vaccinations that were not covered by the inoculation message in Phase 1.

Attitudes towards target topic and related topics:
Following prior inoculation research (e.g., Ivanov et al., 2013), participants will rate the target topic (vaccine safety) and the (in pilot study established) related attitude topics (e.g. GMO, flu jab) using seven semantic differential items (negative/positive, bad/good, dislike/like, desirable/undesirable, unfavourable/ favourable, unacceptable/acceptable, and wrong/right). All ratings will be measured through 7-point scales with larger numbers reflecting a more positive attitude towards the target and related topics.

Perceived threat:
The perceived threat measure consists of six semantic differential items, addressing the degree to which participants felt that they might come into contact with arguments that could cause them to re-think their position on the topic. Participants will rate their perceived threat on 6 semantic differential (non-threatening/threatening, not harmful/harmful, not dangerous/dangerous, not risky/risky, calm/anxious, and not scary/scary). All ratings will be made on 7-point scales with larger numbers reflecting greater levels of perceived threat.

Counterarguing:
Counterarguing in response to the attack messages will be evaluated with a single-item measure (Ivanov et al., 2016). After reading the attack message targeting each respective topic, participants will be asked to report the degree to which they counter-argued against the attack message on a 7-point scale with the anchors “I accepted a lot of the arguments offered” (1) and “I thought of a lot of arguments against [the arguments offered]” (7). A single-item measure will be used in this study to mitigate participant fatigue, given that participants were asked to report on four topics. This measure has been shown to be correlated with the results of open-ended counterarguing measures used in prior inoculation research (Miller et al., 2013).

Perceived resistance: 
This is adapted from previous persuasion research on attitude strength (Tormala et al., 2004). Participants will be asked to fill out a single-item measure for each attack message (e.g. "Overall, how difficult was it for you to come up with arguments against the ones you just read?'). Responses to this item will be given on a scale ranging from 1 (not difficult at all) to 7 (very difficult).

Attitude certainty: 
A single-item measure will be presented alongside the attitude scales, asking participants to indicate how confident they are in their attitudes towards each topic on a 7-point Likert scale, ranging from not at all confident (1) to neutral (4) to very confident (7).

Public support:
Based on previous research (van der Linden et al., 2015), public support for vaccines will be assessed with 8 items, which were combined and averaged into a single measure to form a reliable index (prior cronbach’s α = 0.96), example items include; “I believe that vaccines are a safe and reliable way to avoid the spread of preventable diseases”, “I have already vaccinated my children or would do so if I had children” and “I would support policies that require people to vaccinate their children” (1 = strongly disagree - 7 = strongly agree).

Perceived medical consensus:
Participants will be required to indicate their perceived medical consensus on vaccine safety and will be asked to report their perceived safety of vaccines on a 7-point scale from “not safe at all” to “very safe” and by using a slider bar from 0% to 100%.

Based on previous research (van der Linden et al., 2015), public support for vaccines will be assessed with 8 items, which will be combined and averaged into a single measure to form a reliable index (prior cronbach’s α = 0.96). All other muli-item scales will be summed and averaged into an index unless they have poor reliability.

To differentiate the mechanisms of blanket of protection (resistance to the same topic but different arguments) from cross-protection (resistance to attack messages against related yet untreated topics), initial analyses will include examining whether inoculation confers resistance against the target topic even when the attack message does not match the inoculation message (Hypothesis 1). By subtracting the post-test attitude score from the pre-test attitude score, an attitude change score will be established. Thus, a series of ANOVAs will be conducted to compare the attitude change scores, perceived threat, and counterarguing of participants within the inoculation = attack message arguments condition. To test whether more generalised inoculation messages are as effective in conferring resistance as specific messages (Hypothesis 2), a one-way way ANOVA will be conducted. 

Hypothesis 3,4, and 5 aim to examine whether cross-protection to related health topics can occur. If cross-protection is conferred, then inoculated participants should report higher perceived resistance to persuasive argument, perceived threat, and counterarguing regardless of whether the arguments of the attack message matched the inoculation message presented in phase 1. Thus, it is expected that inoculated participants will demonstrate less (negative) attitude change towards the target topic (vaccines) as well as the untreated yet related topics (GMO, blood donations, abortion, AV). Thus, a series of ANOVA will be conducted with the attack message order serving as the control variable. Changes in attitudes towards topics will be assessed through pre-post attitude measures, with smaller values indicating greater resistance to attack messages. 

The same analyses using ANCOVAs (with post-test as the DV, condition as a factor and pre-test as a covariate) will also be considered, especially if there are significant baseline variations on the pre-test measures across conditions.

q21.value: two-tailed tests, p < 0.05, correcting for multipe comparisons.

q23.value: Incomplete data will not be included in the analysis.

q24.value:
As the hypotheses and analyses listed above will mainly examine whether cross-protection takes place, additional exploratory analyses are planned to investigate the boundary conditions of when and how cross-protection might occur. Additionally to these confirmatory analyses, some more exploratory examinations such as how attitude certainty or perceived medical consensus might effect cross-protection and whether cross-protection impacts public support of vaccinations will be conducted. Lastly, we hope to further explore the role of counterarguing, threat, and perceived resistance might play in conferring cross-protection. We expect to run a regression analysis on this. 

Additionally, the follow-up study will also allow us to see whether and to what extent blanket of protection and/or cross-protection decay.

registration_responses.q1: Attitudinal cross-protection against health misinformation through inoculation.
registration_responses.q2: Melisa Basol, Dr. Sander van der Linden
registration_responses.q3: Although conferring attitudinal resistance through inoculation has been demonstrated in an array of contexts, very little research has examined the possibility of cross-protection conferred through inoculation. Indeed, Parker and colleagues (2016) were among the first to demonstrate that an inoculation message targeting one topic can confer resistance to conceptually related topics. As equally indicated by the authors, some more specific insights into the mechanisms and boundaries of cross-protection are required. Thus, this suggested study aims to examine whether cross-protection to health misinformation can be conferred through inoculation.
registration_responses.q4:
Hypothesis 1: Compared to the control condition, inoculated participants who receive either of the attack messages addressing the safety and efficacy of the target attitude (vaccines) will demonstrate a general attitudinal resistance (blanket of protection) to either attack message (same or different arguments to inoculation message).  

Hypothesis 2:  Compared to the individuals who were exposed to the attack message that addressed the same arguments as the inoculation treatment on vaccine safety and efficacy,  participants who are exposed to an attack message using different arguments will report (a) equal if not less attitude change, (b) perceived threat, (c) and counterarguing. 

Hypothesis 3: Compared to the control group, participants who receive an inoculation message addressing the safety and efficacy of vaccines (a) will perceive greater levels of threat, (b) are more likely to counterargue, and (c) will experience less negative attitude change in response to either attack message (same/different arguments) against vaccines. 

Hypothesis 4: Compared to the control condition, participants who receive an inoculation message addressing the efficacy and safety of vaccines will (a) report greater counterarguing and (b) perceived threat to their attitudes about (1) GMO, (2) blood donations, and (3) abortion. This is not expected to be present for (4) autonomous vehicles. 

Hypothesis 5: Compared to participants in the control condition, participants who receive an inoculation message addressing the safety and efficacy of vaccines report less (negative) attitude change in response to messages attacking the safety of (1) GMO, (2) blood donations, and (3) abortion. This is not expected to be present for (4) autonomous vehicles.
registration_responses.q5: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.
q6: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.
registration_responses.q9: This study will utilise block randomisation, where each participant will be randomly assigned to one of the three equally sized, predetermined treatment conditions.
registration_responses.q10: Registration prior to creation of data
registration_responses.q11: The only pre-existing data used in this study is a pilot test that required participants (N=130) to fill out attitude scales on a number of topics (e.g. climate change, immigration, autonomous vehicles, blood donations etc.). Correlational analyses allowed to determine which attitudes were correlated with attitudes towards the target topic (vaccination) of the proposed study. Thus, results informed the proposed research to include attitudes towards GMO, abortion, blood donation, and an uncorrelated topic, attitudes towards AV when testing whether inoculation can confer cross-protection across health misinformation.
registration_responses.q13: Based on the power analysis conducted prior to data collection, the required sample size is 296. As we expect some attrition in the follow-up, we will attempt to recruit up to 350 participants.
registration_responses.q14: Taking the average effect size from previous cross-protection research (Ivanov et al., 2016), a G*power analysis was conducted with α = 0.05, F= 3.02 (d= 0.21) and power of 0.95 with four experimental conditions (Phase 2 split into attack_same/attack_diff for both inoculation and control condition). The minimal sample size required for measuring the main effect was approximately 296.
registration_responses.q21: two-tailed tests, p < 0.05, correcting for multipe comparisons.
registration_responses.q23: Incomplete data will not be included in the analysis.
registration_responses.q24:
As the hypotheses and analyses listed above will mainly examine whether cross-protection takes place, additional exploratory analyses are planned to investigate the boundary conditions of when and how cross-protection might occur. Additionally to these confirmatory analyses, some more exploratory examinations such as how attitude certainty or perceived medical consensus might effect cross-protection and whether cross-protection impacts public support of vaccinations will be conducted. Lastly, we hope to further explore the role of counterarguing, threat, and perceived resistance might play in conferring cross-protection. We expect to run a regression analysis on this. 

Additionally, the follow-up study will also allow us to see whether and to what extent blanket of protection and/or cross-protection decay.
registration_responses.q8.question:
This study will implement a 2-phase procedure, applying a 2 (treatment vs. control condition) x 5 (attitude topic) between-subject design. Whilst the independent variable will consist of treatment conditions (inoculation, control),  the dependent variables will constitute of pre- and post-test measures (attitudes, perceived threat, counterarguing, public support) - measured through semantic differential items similar to previous research (Ivanov et a., 2016). This proposed study received ethical approval from the Psychology Research Ethics Committee.  

Procedure: In Phase 1, all participants will complete a pre-test which will require them to fill out attitude scales towards the target topic (vaccines) and the related topics (e.g. GMO, abortion). Then, participants will be randomly assigned to either the control condition or the inoculation condition. Whilst the control condition will be exposed to a neutral and unrelated article, participants in the inoculation condition will be exposed to a paragraph (1) warning about common arguments against vaccine safety and efficacy (2) and providing counterarguments against these arguments. All participants will then be asked to complete the Post-treatment measures (Threat, perceived resistance, confidence, perceived medical consensus + risk, public support). 

After a 1 week delay, all participants will be recontacted to take part in Phase 2 of the study. Here, all participants will be presented with one of two attack messages addressing the target topic (vaccines). Specifically, participants will either read an attack message addressing the same arguments as the inoculation message in Phase 1 (attack_same) or an attack message that uses different arguments (attack_diff). After exposure to either attack_target message, all participants will be exposed to 4 attack messages on the related topics (GMO, abortion, blood donations, AV). Whilst these will be randomised, participants will be required to complete a few measures after each message (counterarguing, perceived resistance, and confidence). After having been exposed to all attack messages, participants will complete the Post-test t2. 

A study-flow chart has been attached for additional clarity.
registration_responses.q12.question: Participants (n= 350)  will be recruited through an online crowd-sourcing platform Prolific Academic. The advertisement will suggest that the study aims to examine opinion on current media topics and will offer a compensation rate of £1.04 for their participation in Part 1 (estimated completion time approx. 10 min) and £0.74 for the follow-up study a week later (approx. completion time: 5 min). Inclusion criteria require participants to be at least 18 years old and speak English fluently.
registration_responses.q16.question: In this study, the attack message will be manipulated. Thus, in the second phase of the study, participants will either be exposed to (1) an attack message addressing the same arguments as the inoculation message (attack_same) or (2) an attack message raising different arguments against vaccinations that were not covered by the inoculation message in Phase 1.
registration_responses.q17.question:
Attitudes towards target topic and related topics:
Following prior inoculation research (e.g., Ivanov et al., 2013), participants will rate the target topic (vaccine safety) and the (in pilot study established) related attitude topics (e.g. GMO, flu jab) using seven semantic differential items (negative/positive, bad/good, dislike/like, desirable/undesirable, unfavourable/ favourable, unacceptable/acceptable, and wrong/right). All ratings will be measured through 7-point scales with larger numbers reflecting a more positive attitude towards the target and related topics.

Perceived threat:
The perceived threat measure consists of six semantic differential items, addressing the degree to which participants felt that they might come into contact with arguments that could cause them to re-think their position on the topic. Participants will rate their perceived threat on 6 semantic differential (non-threatening/threatening, not harmful/harmful, not dangerous/dangerous, not risky/risky, calm/anxious, and not scary/scary). All ratings will be made on 7-point scales with larger numbers reflecting greater levels of perceived threat.

Counterarguing:
Counterarguing in response to the attack messages will be evaluated with a single-item measure (Ivanov et al., 2016). After reading the attack message targeting each respective topic, participants will be asked to report the degree to which they counter-argued against the attack message on a 7-point scale with the anchors “I accepted a lot of the arguments offered” (1) and “I thought of a lot of arguments against [the arguments offered]” (7). A single-item measure will be used in this study to mitigate participant fatigue, given that participants were asked to report on four topics. This measure has been shown to be correlated with the results of open-ended counterarguing measures used in prior inoculation research (Miller et al., 2013).

Perceived resistance: 
This is adapted from previous persuasion research on attitude strength (Tormala et al., 2004). Participants will be asked to fill out a single-item measure for each attack message (e.g. "Overall, how difficult was it for you to come up with arguments against the ones you just read?'). Responses to this item will be given on a scale ranging from 1 (not difficult at all) to 7 (very difficult).

Attitude certainty: 
A single-item measure will be presented alongside the attitude scales, asking participants to indicate how confident they are in their attitudes towards each topic on a 7-point Likert scale, ranging from not at all confident (1) to neutral (4) to very confident (7).

Public support:
Based on previous research (van der Linden et al., 2015), public support for vaccines will be assessed with 8 items, which were combined and averaged into a single measure to form a reliable index (prior cronbach’s α = 0.96), example items include; “I believe that vaccines are a safe and reliable way to avoid the spread of preventable diseases”, “I have already vaccinated my children or would do so if I had children” and “I would support policies that require people to vaccinate their children” (1 = strongly disagree - 7 = strongly agree).

Perceived medical consensus:
Participants will be required to indicate their perceived medical consensus on vaccine safety and will be asked to report their perceived safety of vaccines on a 7-point scale from “not safe at all” to “very safe” and by using a slider bar from 0% to 100%.
registration_responses.q18.question: Based on previous research (van der Linden et al., 2015), public support for vaccines will be assessed with 8 items, which will be combined and averaged into a single measure to form a reliable index (prior cronbach’s α = 0.96). All other muli-item scales will be summed and averaged into an index unless they have poor reliability.
registration_responses.q19.question:
To differentiate the mechanisms of blanket of protection (resistance to the same topic but different arguments) from cross-protection (resistance to attack messages against related yet untreated topics), initial analyses will include examining whether inoculation confers resistance against the target topic even when the attack message does not match the inoculation message (Hypothesis 1). By subtracting the post-test attitude score from the pre-test attitude score, an attitude change score will be established. Thus, a series of ANOVAs will be conducted to compare the attitude change scores, perceived threat, and counterarguing of participants within the inoculation = attack message arguments condition. To test whether more generalised inoculation messages are as effective in conferring resistance as specific messages (Hypothesis 2), a one-way way ANOVA will be conducted. 

Hypothesis 3,4, and 5 aim to examine whether cross-protection to related health topics can occur. If cross-protection is conferred, then inoculated participants should report higher perceived resistance to persuasive argument, perceived threat, and counterarguing regardless of whether the arguments of the attack message matched the inoculation message presented in phase 1. Thus, it is expected that inoculated participants will demonstrate less (negative) attitude change towards the target topic (vaccines) as well as the untreated yet related topics (GMO, blood donations, abortion, AV). Thus, a series of ANOVA will be conducted with the attack message order serving as the control variable. Changes in attitudes towards topics will be assessed through pre-post attitude measures, with smaller values indicating greater resistance to attack messages. 

The same analyses using ANCOVAs (with post-test as the DV, condition as a factor and pre-test as a covariate) will also be considered, especially if there are significant baseline variations on the pre-test measures across conditions.

attributes.title: Therapist Racial Bias: A Meta-Analysis
attributes.description: A meta-analysis of psychotherapist racial bias.

q2.value: Lisa Scott, Timothy Smith, Derek Griner, Kristina Hansen, Austin Davis, Loriana Goulding, Niyeli Herrera, Jarom Hickenlooper, Parker Jarman, Hanna Prieto, Christina Tsoi

q3.value: A meta-analysis of psychotherapist racial bias in treatment.

q4.value: We predict that clients of color will be treated differently by mental health professionals after accounting for initial symptoms.

q5.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
This meta-analysis will evaluate data on the degree to which therapists provide different evaluations/responses based solely on client race. The review process for this study began September 28, 2004 and was temporarily halted October 17, 2007. The project was picked up once more April 11, 2019. This review is currently in the process of extracting data from studies (coding), but the data has yet to be analyzed. A final round of searching for manuscripts will be completed by June, 2020. This review and all team members are affiliated with Brigham Young University. All funding for this project was provided by Brigham Young University. The authors have no known conflicts of interest.

This review explores the questions: to what extent do mental health professionals demonstrate different evaluations of and responses to clients based solely on client race (after controlling for symptoms)? To what extent is this effect moderated by client and therapist characteristics (e.g., age, gender, and race), and by study characteristics? Articles will be collected by searching through EBSCO databases (PsycINFO, Academic Search Premier, Academic Search Ultimate, Family & Society Studies Worldwide, MEDLINE, Social Work Abstracts, Women’s Studies International), Embase, and Google Scholar. Our search string can be found here: https://docs.google.com/document/d/1lrF44V9Sx0dNGFy8x_w2fq_1GqNMJa6F5ctsAxcRh48/edit?usp=sharing. 

Inclusion criteria have been outlined and followed in the gathering of articles. Studies that measure therapist bias have been included, while studies measuring testing or measurement bias have not. Only studies conducted in the United States or Canada have been included. Studies were included if they were written in English, Spanish, Portuguese, French or Chinese. This was decided based on the research teams’ language abilities. Studies that include mental health professionals have been included. “Mental health professional” is defined as physicians, psychiatrists, psychiatric nurses, psychologists and counselors (and graduate students and interns in those disciplines). This definition does not include career/vocational counselors, substance abuse counselors, school counselors or school psychologists. Studies have been included that include a mix of professionals. The services included were any service intended to evaluate mental health and/or enhance mental health in some way. Clients could have been vignette descriptions or actual clients, and at least some of the clients were people of color compared across races. Clients could have been seen individually, as a couple, as a family or in a group. Clients must have had a diagnosis as found in the DSM-5 or ICD-10, or have the likely possibility of such a condition, excluding substance abuse or career struggles. Only quantitative research designs have been included, and case studies and single-N studies have been excluded. In addition, studies from any year have been included. Articles were included if they were either journal articles, book chapters, books, dissertations, or conference presentations. 

Potential independent and dependent variables were also outlined in the inclusion criteria. Possible independent variables include client race/ethnicity, therapist-reported white privilege attitudes, therapist racial/ethnic comfort or discomfort, and client-perceived cultural humility of the counselor. Possible dependent variables include therapist judgement of client severity, diagnosis, prognosis or the experience of abuse and/or trauma (controlling for symptoms/severity in some way), therapist judgement of client attributes, characteristics or behaviors, therapist treatment recommendations (controlling for symptoms/severity), therapist self-perception of own comfort or ability to work with clients across different races, client perceptions of therapist bias, and client-reported counseling outcomes or termination of treatment (when the independent variable is an indicator of therapist bias). The main outcome being evaluated is (1) differences between patients of different races, coded using Cohen’s d, or (2) correlation of measures of therapist bias with client variables relevant to mental health treatment, coded using Pearson r.  No additional outcomes will be evaluated.

q11.value: We have begun coding articles. We have not analyzed the data. We will wait to do this until after all of the articles have been coded.

q13.value: We are conducting an exhaustive literature search and do not yet know the total number of studies to be included. So far, we have identified over 100 studies.

q14.value: We are gathering every relevant article we can find in the databases we included.

question.value: Potential independent and dependent variables were outlined in the inclusion criteria. Independent variables include client race/ethnicity, therapist-reported white privilege attitudes, therapist racial/ethnic comfort or discomfort, and client-perceived cultural humility of the counselor. Dependent variables include therapist judgement of client severity, diagnosis, prognosis or the experience of abuse and/or trauma (controlling for symptoms/severity in some way), therapist judgement of client attributes, characteristics or behaviors, therapist treatment recommendations (controlling for symptoms/severity), therapist self-perception of own comfort or ability to work with clients across different races, client perceptions of therapist bias, and client-reported counseling outcomes or termination of treatment (when the independent variable is an indicator of therapist bias). The main outcomes being evaluated are (1) differences between patients of different races, coded using Cohen’s d, or (2) correlation of measures of therapist bias with client variables relevant to mental health treatment, coded using Pearson r.

Omnibus analyses will be conducted using random effects weighted models. Only one estimate per study will be included in omnibus analyses. When a study reports more than one effect size those values will be averaged weighted by N, or standard error. 
Estimates of heterogeneity will be calculated. If statistically significant heterogeneity is found subsequent analyses will be conducted to identify sources of heterogeneity (moderator analyses). For those analyses, random effects weighted correlations will be calculated between continuous variables and effect size. Random effects weighted analyses of variance will be calculated for categorical variables. 
Estimates of publication bias will include trim and fill methodology, visual inspection of funnel plots, and calculation of Beggs regression coefficient.

q20.value: We are using online effect size calculators to transform all statistics into either Cohen's d or Pearson's r.

q23.value: Missing data characterize all meta-analyses. We will conduct analyses only with extracted information from studies and not impute any values.

summary.value: This registration includes the measures and materials documents for Study 1 and Study 2 of this project, as well as the preregistration document for hypotheses and analytic plan for both studies.

registration_responses.summary: This registration includes the measures and materials documents for Study 1 and Study 2 of this project, as well as the preregistration document for hypotheses and analytic plan for both studies.

q3.value: Students in Campaigns and Elections (12 students) are asked to recruit 3 captains and to make a list of 20 people they know who are eligible to vote in the March 3, 2020 primary election. Each captain is also asked to make such a list. All lists (4x20x12=960 people total in pool) are then randomized into equal treatment and control groups. Students are responsible for urging the 10 people on their treatment list to vote, and for reminding their captains to do the same. There is no specific message or tactic; students are supposed to use their interpersonal relationships to urge turnout as they see appropriate. After the election, we will compare turnout between the treatment and control groups, clustered by captain and student, to see if they were able to increase participation.

q4.value:
1. Potential voters on the treatment lists will be more likely to vote than potential voters on the control lists.
2. Students who are more effective will also have more effective captains.
3. Potential voters who live on campus or are associated with Menlo College will be more strongly affected by the GOTV efforts than non-Menlo potential voters.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: Personnel who interact directly with the study subjects (either human or non-human subjects) will not be aware of the assigned treatments. (Commonly known as “double blind”)

question.value: Lists of potential voters will be collected and randomized by Dr. Michelson. Students will then instruct their captains of their lists of 10 voters and the assignment. Students will work as they see fit to mobilize their lists of 10 treatment voters and their captains to maximize turnout in the treatment groups. Dr. Michelson will check the validated turnout files after the election to compare turnout in the treatment and control groups. This is a pretty simple experimental design.

q9.value: Lists will be randomized using the RANDOMIZE block in Stata, clustered at the household level (or dorm room level, for on-campus students with roommates).

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Subjects will be recruited by students in Campaigns and Elections class. Students are encouraged to use students or other local people to make their lists (to allow for deep mobilization efforts) but can also choose to include individuals who live further away, e.g. in their hometowns). Lists of potential voters and recruited captains are due on Thursday, Feb. 20, 2020. Lists will be returned to students on Friday, Feb. 21, 2020. Reminders about mobilizing voters on the treatment lists will be repeated in class on Tuesday, Feb. 25, Thursday, Feb. 27, and Election Day, Tuesday, March 3. Data will be examined when available from the county registrars, likely in mid-April.

comments.value:
Fragestellung: Welche Auswirkung hat die Intervention mit einem Chat-Bot auf die Selbstwirksamkeit von Personen, im Vergleich zu Personen die eine Intervention erhalten ohne Chat-Bot?

Hypothese: Personen, die eine Intervention mit einem Chat-Bot erhalten, zeigen eine signifikant höhere Selbstwirksamkeit in Bezug auf die Umsetzung ihrer Vorhaben als Personen, die eine Intervention ohne einen Chat-Bot erhalten haben.

2 Variablen: 
1 UV (Einfaktoriell): Intervention mit/ohne Chat-Bot (2 Faktorenstufen)
1 AV (Univariat): Selbstwirksamkeit

Einschlusskriterien: 
-Zwischen 18-35
-Deutschsprachig
-Emotional stabil
-Zugang zu einem Computer mit Internetverbindung
